answers.author: John Zakian
answers.text:
It was more than a decade ago that I led a senior management team in an identical assesment and I can offer lessons learned foremost of which is to select a firm without a vested interest meaning one without units or subsidiaries primarily delivering some or all of the services you seek to assess.  While I believe the firm we used did give us an honest and thorough assessment, unfortunately we had to address a public perception of its bias in that it also had subsidiaries which delivered the services that were assessed.  I would definitely, therefore, recommend that the "qualifications" of respondants include a stipluation that it not have subsidiaries or divisions which sell or contract out services, programs, and/or equipment to be assessed.

author: Danielle Casey
text: Our City is seeking to commission a 3rd party audit of our IT department, from an infrastructure perspective as well as resource standpoint. We are seeking to find out where we stand and what improvements need to be made to processes and procedures, workspace, positions, centralized vs decentralized services, customer service, reporting division, and opportunities for outsourcing various portions. Does anyone have names of professional service firms that have conducted these types of audits, or examples of a scope of service used?
title: Audit of Information Technology/Technology Services Department
